content:
• Thursday, May 28, 2015
  • YAHOY

    Yahoo Japan jumps on China alliance with Alibaba

    • Yahoo Japan (OTCPK:YAHOY) is up 8.6% in Tokyo, the biggest single-day jump in two months, as it says it's looking to team with Alibaba Group (NYSE:BABA) to enter China's e-commerce market.
    • The company -- Japan's third-largest e-tailer -- will help guide Japanese companies to sell products, especially household goods, on Alibaba's Tmall and Tmall Global sites.
    • Japanese goods' increasing popularity in China is providing expansion opportunities, Yahoo Japan (a JV between Softbank (OTCPK:SFTBY) and Yahoo (YHOO)) noted in a statement.
    • Softbank is up 1.7% in Tokyo.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:21 PM | 8 Comments
  • RST

    Rosetta Stone +10%; P-E group reportedly makes buyout offer

    • Mergermarket reports a group of P-E investors have offered to buy Rosetta Stone (NYSE:RST) for $9-$10/share. The language software vendor has jumped to $7.07 in AH trading.
    • The rumored buyout price range is still well below the levels Rosetta traded at two years ago. Mergermarket's report comes two months after CEO Stephen Swad resigned, and was replaced on an interim basis by director/ex-Goldman partner A. John Hass.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:31 PM
  • MEET

    MeetMe CTO Friedman resigns

    • MeetMe (NASDAQ:MEET) discloses CTO Richard Friedman is resigning, effective June 3. He "may serve as a consultant" through year's end, for which MeetMe will pay him bi-weekly installments of $3,802.15.
    • MEET -2% AH to $1.49.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:55 PM | 13 Comments
  • DECK

    Deckers returns post-earnings gains; FQ1 outlook soft

    • Initially up in AH trading following its FQ4 beat, Deckers (NASDAQ:DECK) is now down 1.9% to $69.88. Likely weighing: The footwear maker is guiding for FQ1 revenue to be flat Y/Y, and for EPS of -$1.52. Consensus is for a 7.7% revenue increase and EPS of -$1.17.
    • FY16 (ends March '16) guidance is stronger: Revenue of $1.96B and EPS of $5.09, slightly above a consensus of $1.95B and $5.05.
    • Business performance: FQ4 UGG sales +9.7% Y/Y to $216.8M; Teva +13.4% to $53.1M; Sanuk +27.9% to $39.2M. Wholesale/distributor sales +16.6% to $205.1M; retail stores +7.7% to $86.3M; e-commerce +27.4% to $49.2M. 30 new retail store openings offset a 6.5% same-store sales decline. U.S. sales +9.8% to $217.7M; international +27.5% to $122.9M.
    • Financials: Gross margin fell 420 bps Y/Y to 44.7%. Inventories rose 12.9% to $238.9M. $93.9M was spent to buy back 1.3M shares. Deckers ended FQ4 with $225.1M in cash, and $5.4M in credit facility borrowings.
    • FQ4 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:49 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers: EDAP +19.5%. OCLR +3.13%. EDUC +3%. ONTY +1.78%. URBN +1.76%.
    • Top losers: MSCC -5.36%. GLNG -2.71%. SHLD -2.45%. AMRN  -1.7%. AWAY -1.3%. 
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 2 Comments
  • GME

    GameStop up 3.9% as Q1 beats on top, bottom lines

    • GameStop (NYSE:GME) is up 3.9% in postmarket trading after reporting Q1 profits that grew 15%, easily beating expectations, on revenues boosted by dozens of new stores and strong digital pickup.
    • Same-store sales were up 8.6%. In the prior-year quarter, same-store sales had risen 5.8%.
    • Revenues of $2.06B were up 3.2%, but up 8.1% in constant currency. New software sales rose 9.6% (15.8% in constant currency).
    • Diversifying its offering was paying benefits: Non-GAAP digital receipts rose a healthy 17.2% to $222.2M. Sales in mobile and consumer electronics rose 33.9% to $136.8M.
    • GameStop bought back $46.4M of stock in Q1, and has just over $400M left on its current repurchase authorization.
    • The company provided in-line guidance for Q2 EPS of $0.21-$0.25, and raised guidance for full-year EPS to $3.63-$3.83 to account for a reduction in shares (which is on the low side of an expected $3.84 EPS). It expects comparable-store sales should range from flat to +3% for Q2, and +1% to +6% for 2015.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:23 PM
  • SPLK

    Splunk -3% in spite of beat-and-raise quarter; license revenue up 40%

    • As was the case following its FQ4 beat, high expectations are weighing on Splunk (NASDAQ:SPLK) following its FQ1 beat and guidance hike: Shares were up 20% YTD going into earnings, and trading at 14.5x the midpoint of the company's increased FY16 sales guidance range (still quite possibly conservative, given Splunk's guidance history).
    • Business performance: FQ1 License revenue (drives future maintenance revenue) +40% Y/Y to $71.9M, a slight slowdown from FQ4's 43%. Maintenance/services revenue +55% to $53.8M. 450+ new customers were added, down from 600+ in seasonally strong FQ4 but up from 400+ a year ago, and bringing the total base above 9,500 (inc. 80 of the Fortune 100). With billings outgrowing revenue, the deferred revenue balance rose 57% to $305.3M.
    • Financials: GAAP gross margin fell 180 bps Y/Y to 81.6%. Operating expenses rose 43% to $173.6M - sales/marketing spend totaled $101.9M, R&D $44.7M, and G&A $26.9M. Splunk ended FQ1 with $1.04B in cash/investments, and no debt.
    • FY16 op. margin guidance of 2%-3% has been maintained. FQ2 guidance is at 1%-2%.
    • Shares have fallen to $68.85 AH.
    • FQ1 results/guidance, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:20 PM | 7 Comments
  • ULTA

    E-commerce dazzles for Ulta Salon in Q1

    • Ulta Salon (NASDAQ:ULTA) recorded another strong quarter of growth backed by a 50% rise in e-commerce sales.
    • Comparable-store sales were up 11.4%.
    • Salon sales +20.5% to $51.3M.
    • Gross profit rate +40 bps to 34.5%.
    • SG&A expense rate -60 bps to 22.2%.
    • Previously: Ulta Salon beats by $0.11, beats on revenue
    • ULTA +1.50% after hours to $158.60.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:09 PM
  • MX

    MagnaChip +3.6%; CEO/CFO get interim tags removed, others resign

    • After holding the positions for the last year on an interim basis, YJ Kim has been named MagnaChip's (NYSE:MX) permanent CEO and Jonathan Kim its permanent CFO, the company discloses in its Q1 report.
    • Also disclosed: HK Kim, GM of MagnaChip's Power Solutions (power management chip) business, and Brent Rowe, the company's sales chief, have resigned. The departures follow the recent resignation of COO Tae Young Hwang.
    • YJ Kim: "We continue to face major challenges as a result of strategic missteps in the past, so we have implemented a comprehensive cost and portfolio optimization program to position MagnaChip for growth over the long-term while we also work to improve fab utilization and boost engineering efficiencies." As part of the effort, MagnaChip has combined its Power Solutions and Display Solutions (display IC) ops into a single Standard Products unit.
    • Shares have risen to $6.62 AH.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:55 PM
  • GEF

    Greif cuts 2015 EPS guidance by ~25%

    • Greif (NYSE:GEF) -13.1% AH after lowering guidance for its FY 2015 adjusted EPS to $1.65-$1.75 from its earlier outlook of $2.25-$2.35.
    • GEF says the principal factors contributing to the downward guidance are based on recent results and near term expectations on lower volumes and gross margins for the company's North American businesses, and the continuing impact of unfavorable foreign exchange rates.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:39 PM
  • VEEV

    Veeva down 4.2% after FQ1 beat, in-line sales guidance

    • Though Veeva (NYSE:VEEV) beat FQ1 estimates, revenue guidance is only in-line: FQ2 revenue of $95M-$96M vs. a $95.6M consensus, and FY16 (ends Jan. '16) revenue of $393M-$397M vs. a $395.2M consensus.
    • FQ2 EPS guidance of $0.11 is in-line, while FY16 guidance of $0.45-$0.46 is above a $0.44 consensus.
    • Business performance: Subscription revenue +42% Y/Y to $68.9M; professional services/other +15% to $21M. The deferred revenue balance rose 49% Y/Y to $111.3M. New customer wins included cloud CRM software rollout with GSK, a Veeva Network (cloud master data software) win with a top-20 pharma company, and a Veeva Vault (cloud clinical trial content software) win with a top-20 pharma company.
    • Financials: Gross margin rose 140 bps Y/Y to 77.9%. Operating expenses (non-GAAP) rose 28% Y/Y to $33M (compares with 35% revenue growth). Veeva ended FQ1 with $428.5M in cash/short-term investments, and no debt.
    • Shares have fallen to $27.78 AH.
    • FQ1 results, PR.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM | 3 Comments
  • ULTA

    Ulta Salon beats by $0.11, beats on revenue

    • Ulta Salon (NASDAQ:ULTA): FQ1 EPS of $1.04 beats by $0.11.
    • Revenue of $868.1M (+21.6% Y/Y) beats by $21.78M.
    • Shares +1.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM
  • DECK

    Deckers Outdoor beats by $0.04, beats on revenue

    • Deckers Outdoor (NASDAQ:DECK): FQ4 EPS of $0.04 beats by $0.04.
    • Revenue of $340.64M (+15.6% Y/Y) beats by $19.4M.
    • Shares +4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM
  • GME

    GameStop beats by $0.09, beats on revenue

    • GameStop (NYSE:GME): Q1 EPS of $0.68 beats by $0.09.
    • Revenue of $2.06B (+3.5% Y/Y) beats by $50M.
    • Shares +7.11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:07 PM | 4 Comments
  • SEDG

    SolarEdge makes fresh post-IPO highs after Canaccord target hike

    • Following upbeat investor meetings, Canaccord has hiked its SolarEdge (SEDG +3.1%) target by $6 to $43, while reiterating a Buy.
    • With the help of a blowout FQ3 report, the solar inverter/power optimizer maker is now up 111% from its $18 March IPO price, and 90% from a post-IPO opening trade of $20.00.
    • Shares trade for 3.5x a possibly conservative FY16 (ends June '16) revenue consensus of $431.9M (implies 34.2% Y/Y growth).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • URI

    United Rentals plunges on indications of weak May sales

    • United Rentals (URI -9.3%) sinks nearly 10% following earlier comments by CEO Michael Kneeland and other top execs at a KeyBanc conference presentation that May revenue would come in a "little softer" than previously expected.
    • When asked about utilization rates so far in May, CFO William Plummer said "May is coming in a little softer than we had in mind at that point [on the last quarter earnings call], and that's certainly something that we're focused on to try to understand what might be driving that."
    • Peer Terex (TEX -7.4%) also is sharply lower near the close.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 6 Comments
  • AMRN

    Amarin bags favorable court ruling on Vascepa NCE market exclusivity

    • Amarin (AMRN +18.2%) jumps on a 6x surge in volume in response to its announcement that the federal district court for the District of Columbia has granted the company's motion for summary judgement in its case against the FDA seeking an order requiring the regulator to recognize five-year marketing exclusivity for Vascepa (icosapent ethyl) as a New Chemical Entity (NCE). The company believes the market exclusivity period should extend through July 25, 2017, five years after the FDA's approval in July 2012.
    • The court's ruling also confirms that the FDA cannot accept Abbreviated New Drug Applications (ANDAs) for generic versions of icosapent ethyl until July 2016. The automatic 30-month statutory stay triggered by the submission of an ANDA would push approvals out until January 2020.
    • Amarin plans to dismiss current Vascepa patent litigation related to previously submitted ANDAs.
    • The company has another lawsuit pending against the FDA seeking authorization to communicate ANCHOR clinical trial data to doctors.
    • Previously: Amarin sues FDA to allow it to communicate ANCHOR results to docs (May 7)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 19 Comments
  • ZNGA

    Zynga up 3% as it launches new match-3 game

    • Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) is up 3.2% on a day where it's launched FarmVille: Harvest Swap, a new effort to take some share from monsters like Candy Crush Saga in the Match-3 puzzle game genre.
    • Zynga says more than 60% of gamers play Match-3 style games, and nearly 75% of FarmVille players are fans of the genre. FarmVille has been downloaded more than 700M times, and the new game leverages that user base by allowing players to earn resources across the various FarmVille games.
    • The company promises a fresh take on the game mode, with drag-or-swipe function added to the swap mechanic, as well as a larger storyline that requires puzzle-solving for advancement.
    • Zynga discussed its strategic refocus (with particular emphasis on mobile) during recent conference calls -- it now focuses on five categories, Action Strategy, Social Casino, Invest & Express, Casual and Racing -- and while the original FarmVille lives in its Invest & Express group, the company considers the new entry part of its Casual group.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:28 PM | 3 Comments
  • SD

    SandRidge's planned $1B notes sale adds to debt concerns

    • SandRidge Energy (SD -1.6%) tumbles as much as 11% before rebounding, on news it plans to raise $1B of new debt to pay down its credit facility and bolster its cash balance.
    • SD's long-term debt now totals ~$3.36B - a lot of debt for a company with an enterprise value just over $5B - and the new plan adds to concerns about SD's future, but the new debt will boost overall liquidity and buy time while SD addresses its problems.
    • As Motley Fool's Matt DiLallo notes, raising new debt is an odd way to deal with a debt problem so it remains to be seen if other moves are in the works.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM | 10 Comments
  • INSG

    Novatel down 10.6% following news of COO's departure

    • Novatel (MIFI) has tumbled to its lowest levels since January after disclosing yesterday afternoon COO Slim Souissi plans to leave.
    • The 4G router/M2M module maker now trades for only 0.8x a 2015 revenue consensus of $262.9M, and 0.7x a 2016 consensus of $302.7M.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM
  • AMSC

    AMSC -4.3% after FQ4 beat, cautious FQ1 guidance

    • Though it beat FQ4 estimates, American Superconductor (NASDAQ:AMSC) is guiding for FQ1 EPS to be "less than" -$0.70; that's unfavorable to a -$0.63 consensus. Revenue guidance of $22M-$24M is in-line with a $23.6M consensus, and slightly below at the midpoint.
    • Financials: FQ4 Wind division revenue (turbine components) +66% Y/Y to $21.2M. Grid division (smart grid components) +12% to $4.1M. SG&A spend fell by $3.8M Y/Y to $5.7M; R&D fell by $200K to $2.9M.
    • Thanks in part to its $8.4M arbitration payment to Ghodawat, AMSC ended FQ4 with $24.5M in cash, down from $37.6M at the end of FQ3. A stock offering expected to yield net proceeds of $22.3M was launched last month.
    • FQ4 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 3:05 PM
  • NAP

    Navios Maritime Midstream boosts EBITDA outlook after vessel acquisition

    • Navios Maritime Midstream (NAP +5.6%) is higher after announcing plans to launch the syndication of a $205M term loan B to finance the acquisition of two vessels from Navios Maritime Acquisition (NNA +0.2%) and the refinance existing debt.
    • NAP projects FY 2015 EBITDA, based on its current fleet of four VLCCs, at $53.1M, but pro forma EBITDA for a fleet of six VLCCs following the acquisitions is seen at $76.2M.
    • Also: NM -1.6%, NMM -0.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:41 PM | 10 Comments
  • SKX

    New all-time high for sizzling Skechers

    • Skechers (NYSE:SKX) trades higher after the company issues a statement pointing to industry data showing it's now the second largest athletic footwear seller in the U.S.
    • Also in the background is some loose chatter on Nike making a bid for Skechers.
    • SKX +3.39% to $107.71 on above-average volume. SKX +94.5% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM | 12 Comments
  • SSTK

    Shutterstock up 4.3% on bullish Topeka coverage

    • Shutterstock (NYSE:SSTK) has rallied above $65 after Topeka launched coverage with a Buy rating and $92 target.
    • Topeka: "We expect Shutterstock to continue to take market share from Getty Images ... and benefit from the further adoption of its Video, Audio, and Editorial content." It also expects the competitive impact of Adobe's Fotolia acquisition (led shares to plunge when it was announced) to be minimal, and forecasts a ~30% revenue CAGR and mid-twenties EBITDA margins for the next 3 years.
    • The firm's target is equal to 6x estimated 2016 EV/sales and 40x estimated EPS.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:28 PM
  • ANF

    Sunny day for Abercrombie & Fitch despite Q1 sales slide

    • Shares of Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF +13.6%) rip a double-digit gain on some investor optimism the retailer will see sales declines decelerate in Q2.
    • The company reported a minor beat with Q1 comps, -8% vs. -9% consensus, and has pulled the plug on some of its more unprofitable ventures.
    • During the earnings call, execs spent more time highlighting the future direction of A&F than defending the past as in previous calls.
    • Skeptics are pointing to the writedown of inventory by management as a negative signal.
    • Today's action on ANF could be influenced by some short position covering.
    • Abercrombie & Fitch earnings call webcast
    • Previously: Abercrombie & Fitch misses by $0.19, misses on revenue (May 28)
    • Previously: Sales shrivel at Abercrombie & Fitch in Q1 (May 28)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:43 PM | 1 Comment
  • AVGO

    Avago/Broadcom set long-term targets; Avago offers strong FQ3 guidance

    • In a presentation (.pdf) discussing their planned merger, Avago (AVGO -0.4%) and Broadcom (BRCM -2.6%) state they're aiming for a 40% long-term op. margin, up from the 30% collectively possessed by the companies today. Gross margin is forecast to rise to 60% from a current 57%, and R&D and SG&A spend respectively fall to 16% and 4% of revenue from 20% and 7%.
    • Avago and Broadcom, who have $15.1B in revenue between them, are only forecasting a 5% long-term revenue CAGR. However, Avago CEO Hock Tan states the outlook is "probably conservative."
    • Avago plans to partly finance the $17B cash portion of the deal via $9B worth of new debt. The post-merger company is expected to have $15.5B in debt and $1.3B in cash; Broadcom shareholders will have a 32% stake. The deal is expected to close in Q1 2016.
    • Many potential product synergies exist. Among the possibilities: Wi-Fi/Bluetooth solutions that pair Broadcom's combo chips with Avago RF components; server/storage connectivity product lines featuring a mixture of Broadcom's Ethernet transceivers and switching chips and Avago's adapter cards and optical transceivers - Stifel thinks Mellanox (MLNX -0.3%) could be at risk here - and telecom equipment product lines that combine Broadcom's network processors and switching chips with Avago's optical components.
    • Meanwhile, in its FQ2 report (issued in tandem with the merger announcement), Avago has guided for FQ3 revenue of $1.74B (+/- $25M), above a $1.68B consensus. The company reported a 66% Y/Y increase in FQ2 wireless chip revenue (aided by strong Apple/Samsung demand), along with 74% and 64% increases in wired infrastructure and industrial/other revenue (lifted by both organic growth and M&A).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:34 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: TBIO +23%. VRTB +21%. CHLN +13%. HNR +13%. TUBE +11%. CBLI +11%. ETRM +10%. RWC +9%. XENE +9%. BIOC +9%.
    • Losers: OTC:DCTH -17%. XCRA -16%. SMTC -15%. NVFY -11%. PBMD -11%. IKAN -11%. WILC -11%. MOD -10%. NEPT -9%. GRO -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:47 PM | 2 Comments
  • GPRO

    GoPro +6.5% after drone/VR remarks; Piper, Stifel like what they see

    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) has rallied to its highest levels since January after CEO Nicholas Woodman announced a quadcopter drone and 6-camera spherical array are in the pipeline. Though still down YTD, shares are now up 53% from a March low of $37.13.
    • "We believe the entrance of GoPro into the drone and VR markets could begin to mitigate bear arguments of a small [addressable market] opportunity for GoPro," writes Piper's Erinn Murphy. She notes massive long-term growth is expected for the drone and VR markets (ed: regarding VR, GoPro isn't planning to launch a headset, but an array that can take VR footage), and that top consumer drone maker DJI (believed to have ~70% of the market) could be valued at $8B-$10B in funding talks.
    • Stifel thinks a GoPro drone could respectively boost 2016 sales and EPS by $150M-$200M and $0.20-$0.30 if launched early in the year. The camera array is expected to have a limited impact on 2015/2016 results.
    • Update (3:38PM ET): At Google's I/O conference, GoPro has shown off a 16-camera array capable of shooting 3D VR content.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM | 23 Comments
  • TUBE

    TubeMogul up 11.7% on half-million share volume

    • TubeMogul (NASDAQ:TUBE) is up 11.7% now showing double average volume, on no notable news.
    • Nearly all analysts maintain Buy-level ratings on the stock. JMP Securities reiterated its Outperform rating earlier this month, with a raised price target of $22 (shares trade currently at $17.36). Albert Fried set its price target at $21 while Piper Jaffray raised its target to $25.
    • The stock is up 23.7% over the past three months (but down 24.2% YTD after significant drops in January and February).
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • CREE

    Cree +2.1%; CEO buys 10K shares

    • CREE chairman/CEO Chuck Swoboda discloses he bought 10K shares on Tuesday at $29.32, bringing his total stake to 345K.
    • The purchase is Cree's first insider buy since last October, when director John Replogle bought 5K shares. It comes with Cree continuing to trade more than 50% below its 2013 highs, and 10 days after the company announced IPO plans for its power/RF chip unit.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:31 PM | 12 Comments
  • DANG

    Dangdang -13.1% on Q1 EPS miss, soft Q2 sales guidance

    • Though Dangdang (NYSE:DANG) beat Q1 revenue estimates, EPS of -$0.12 was well below a $0.04 consensus. In addition, the Chinese online retailer has guided for Q2 revenue of RMB2.3B ($371M), below a $378.6M consensus.
    • Hurting Q1 EPS: Gross margin fell to 15.2% from Q4's 17.1% and Q1 2014's 18.2%. Dangdang blames "a larger contribution of general merchandise sales as a percentage of total net revenues and a decline in logistics revenue from third-party merchants." Fulfillment was 9.1% of revenue, marketing 4.3%, tech/content 2.8%, and G&A 2.3%.
    • Business performance: Media revenue +9.5% Y/Y to $203.4M; general merchandise +71.8% to $143.2M; other revenue +1.9% to $11.1M. Active customers +46% Y/Y to 10.2M; total orders +29% to 21.3M (41% via mobile).
    • Shares are less than $1.50 removed from a 52-week low of $7.49. The company's Q1-ending cash balance of $267.1M is equal to 32% of its $843M market cap.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 12:26 PM | 1 Comment
  • MGEN

    Signal Genetics moves up ahead of corporate presentation on June 1

    • Thinly traded nano cap Signal Genetics (SGNL +30.6%) makes a healthy up move today on a 7x surge in volume. No particular news accounts for the action other than a corporate overview scheduled for the afternoon of June 1 at the LD Micro Invitational.
    • The company, founded in 2010, provides molecular diagnostics services through its CLIA-certified laboratory.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:21 PM
  • DDD

    3D Systems spikes on unconfirmed GE rumor

    • 3D Systems (DDD +3.4%) has spiked higher on an unconfirmed rumor it has hired Goldman to advise on a GE bid in the $30-$34/share range.
    • Many such rumors wind up eventually being shot down. And a huge short interest arguably makes 3D particularly susceptible to moving on one: 37.2M shares (35% of the float) were shorted as of April 30.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:09 AM | 19 Comments
  • IMAX

    New all-time high for IMAX after China IPO development

    • Shares of IMAX (IMAX +5.9%) jump to an all-time high after the company announces plans for a Hong Kong IPO for IMAX China.
    • The slate of Hollywood movies scheduled to be released for the balance of this year and in 2016 is viewed as favorable to IMAX China.
    • Previously: IMAX China files for Hong Kong IPO
     
     
     
     
    | 10:50 AM
  • TLYS

    Tilly's plummets after weak guidance rattles investors

    • Shares of Tilly's (TLYS -22.5%) are under pressure after a soft outlook from the company for Q2 scares off investors.
    • Tilly's set Q2 EPS guidance at $0.01-$0.05 vs. $0.08 consensus off an estimated comp sales range of -2% to +2%.
    • Once again, soft mall traffic was a factor for Tilly's in Q1.
    • A number of investment firms have chopped their own estimates on Tilly's following the report.
    • Previously: Tilly's beats by $0.01, misses on revenue
     
     
     
     
    | 10:37 AM
  • ERIC

    Ericsson +2.3%; Citi upgrades, expects wireless capex to rebound

    • Citi's Ehud Gelblum, upgrading Ericsson (NASDAQ:ERIC) to Buy: "We believe the critical North America market is likely to start showing signs of life in the second half of the year, after remaining moribund for the past six quarters. We believe the recovery extends beyond H2 and continues into 2016 as operators are likely to deploy new equipment post the AWS-3 spectrum auction."
    • With Ericsson (ERIC) having sold off hard last month due to a Q1 miss blamed partly on weak North American 4G spending, Gelblum thinks current levels could represent "a compelling entry point."
    • He also argues cost cuts will help boost margins, that the Nokia/Alcatel-Lucent merger could allow Ericsson to gain share (others have argued the same), and that a resolution of Ericsson's patent battle against Apple would provide a bottom-line boost.
    • The upgrade comes a day after Gelblum downplayed remarks from chairman Leif Johansson indicating Ericsson is open to making a big acquisition. "[A]fter speaking with the company and doing some thinking of our own, we do not believe there has been any change to ERIC’s thinking or approach to M&A. There had already been much speculation Ericsson will respond to Nokia/Alcatel by acquiring a wireline equipment vendor.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:37 AM
  • SALE

    RetailMeNot up 2.8%; Topeka initiates coverage at Buy

    • RetailMeNot (NASDAQ:SALE) is up 2.8% this morning following an initiation of coverage by Topeka Capital Markets at a Buy rating.
    • Analyst Blake Harper set a target price for the firm of $28; shares are trading currently at $21.03.
    • "We view the company's large and fast growing mobile audience, along with its improving mobile monetization and a reasonable valuation as reasons to own the stock," Harper says.

    WDC +5.3%, STX +2.3%; Goldman upgrades Western to Buy

    • Believing its current valuation doesn't take into account strong enterprise/cloud demand, Goldman's Bill Shope has upgraded Western Digital (NYSE:WDC) to Buy, and hiked his target by $16 to $122. As is often the case, Seagate (NASDAQ:STX) is going in the same direction as Western.
    • Shope: "We estimate that PCs will represent 38% of Western Digital's revenue in CY2015, down from nearly 70% in CY2007. As a result, PC volatility is not nearly as big of a driver of fundamentals as it once was." He forecasts PC-related shipments (hurt by both soft PC sales and SSD encroachment) will see a -9% CAGR from 2014-2016, and that enterprise shipments (lifted by cloud/analytics demand and Western's flash storage offerings) will see an 8% CAGR.
    • Western currently trades for 12x estimated FY16 (ends June '16) EPS. Seagate goes for 11x estimated FY16 (ends June '16) EPS.

  • SDRL

    Seadrill's Q1 profit tumbles, sees tough period ahead

    • Seadrill (NYSE:SDRL) -3.3% premarket after reporting better than expected Q1 earnings thanks to cost cuts but warning that the oil services industry continues to face tough times.
    • "The industry continues to face challenging times... Indications suggest the remainder of 2015 will see subdued market conditions and the challenging market continuing into 2016," CEO Per Wullf says.
    • SDRL says Q1 net profit fell to $427M from $3.1B in the year-ago quarter when the figure was helped by one-off gains that included the deconsolidation of Seadrill Partners; revenue inched higher to $1.24B from $1.22B a year ago.
    • Q1 order backlog dropped to $15.4B from $17.2B in Q4; achieved 93% economic utilization for its floater fleet and 98% for its Jack-up fleet.
    • Says Q1 EBITDA was $711M, up from $624M a year earlier, but expects Q2 EBITDA of ~$70M lower Q/Q mainly due to idle time on some of its rigs and the deconsolidation of SeaMex.
    • "Drillers are in a something like three-year recession, and they are not at the bottom of their earnings trend yet," says Bernstein analyst Nicholas Green. "What we need to see is demand improve and we're not seeing that."
